document_title: What is dyslipidemia? Causes, symptoms, prevention
subsection_content:
Many people have lipid disorders but have no obvious symptoms and are often discovered during routine blood tests. Conversely, dyslipidemia can also cause some cardiovascular diseases and symptoms. (3)
Common signs to detect lipid disorders are usually when they affect organs in the body such as the brain, heart, and kidneys:
Chest tightness, pressure in the chest or chest pain;; Difficulty breathing;; Pain, tension and pressure in the neck, jaw, shoulders, back;; Heart beating fast;; Faint.
Leg pain, especially when walking or standing, is a sign of lower limb vascular disease caused by lipid disorders.
Some people with very high cholesterol and triglyceride levels may develop xanthomas (cholesterol deposits that appear around the eyes, ankles or elbows). This condition has not been reported in many cases and is common in familial hyperlipidemia.
